output: Supported commands:
- help                 Show this message

aaditya_surya — builder, dreamer, coder
Δstim = (intensity × novelty × meaning) / repetition
The best way to learn is to build something you care about.
Not every side project has to be useful. Just fun.
Every great dev was once bad at flexbox.
Console.log until you make it.
You miss 100% of the commits you don’t push.
First you hate JavaScript. Then you understand it. Then you hate it again.
No one really knows how Git works. We just pretend.
Sometimes the bug is just a missing semicolon.
‘Works on my machine’ is not a valid excuse.
Read the error message. Seriously.
The best code is the one you don’t have to write.
Sleep on it. The bug will still be there tomorrow, but you’ll see it clearer.
If at first you don’t succeed, `rm -rf` and start again.
There’s always one more edge case.
Don’t over-engineer. Make it work, then make it right.
The real MVP is the rubber duck who listens to your debugging.
Your future self will thank you for writing that comment.
Even senior devs Google ‘how to center a div.’
Commit early, commit often, regret occasionally.
Behind every ‘quick fix’ is a month of tech debt.
Your UI can be ugly if your API is beautiful.
Stack Overflow: therapy for developers since 2008.
Deploying on Friday is brave. Or foolish.
The best feature might be the one you never ship.
Coding is 10% writing and 90% trying to remember what you were doing.
Don’t panic. Just open the console.
The most productive days often start with deleting code.
You’re not stuck. You’re just one ‘aha’ away.
Always name your files like you’ll revisit them at 3AM.
Shipping beats perfection — unless it’s a memory leak.
